text: [Music]
this is David herzen horn I'm a
correspondent for the New York Times
based in Moscow now covering the more
than two week old civic uprising in Kiev
Ukraine where thousands upon thousands
of demonstrators have taken to the
streets furious with the government of
President Viktor Yanukovych the first
sign that something unusual was
happening came just before midnight all
of a sudden there were intermittent
power outages in Kiev something that
residents here say rarely ever happens
and then the lights were out for good at
that point police were mobilizing into
the square with interlocking shields
breaking through barricades they later
cleared out large swaths of this
territory pushing the protesters back
into one segment of the plaza right in
front of their stage but what we saw
also is that even as the authorities
were moving in they were using less
force than they did during a bloody
crackdown on November 30th their
trenches were at their sides but they
weren't used they merely pushed the
protesters back again and again until
they had removed the perimeter and
forced them into a smaller enclosed area
we also saw the strange parallel
situation that we've seen virtually
every night where at some points you
have angry protesters demonstrating
loudly for the resignation of the
government and at the same time one of
the biggest street parties you've ever
seen with music acts on stage people
dancing to keep warm singing along every
hour so they'll sing the Ukrainian
national anthem
it's quite a display of both patriotism
and fury by about 10:30 this morning the
security forces pulled back having left
a rather cleared space at the north and
south entrances to the plaza within
hours those barricades were back up now
what we see re-energized crowds and an
uncertain future here
police have shown they can move in they
can clear the square the demonstrators
are showing their resolve by being out
here again on the stage again in the
plaza so it'll be an exciting few days
ahead
[Music]
